yOHzrEbXuEOE_DjWi8fHrA.text: This better than average gastro pub in Southwark tries to keep its options open by having a somewhat informal front pub area, with a more restaurant-like rear (white tablecloths and all). The menu is also usually split between a pub lunch menu and a full restaurant menu. The food is good, but nothing spectacular and the service is sometimes a little slack.

qdNZecgOAko20N9D784GKg.text: The laughing gravy is a superb little restaurant on Blackfriars Road. Friendly, homely and exceedingly tasty, we were surprised how good it was. Despite not having a booking, we were seated quickly on a Friday evening (there was a brief check, even though the restaurant was empty!) but after that the experience was flawless. The waiting staff are friendly and attentive, and happy to chat about the food and drinks menu. The selection is very good, and they clearly take a lot of pride in their food. Our duck starter with caramel was exceptional, and the mains were excellent. My steak was tender and delicious and my wife's vegetable hash was of similar quality. The mains do vary in price, so it's suitable for less extravagant occasions as well  you can have a burger for ~£10, or rump / sirloin steak for £18-22. The drinks menu is also very good  the wine is a shade expensive, but there's a very good selection of beers and ales as well (including that from very local, very good Kernel Brewery) It's not dressy, and we went in straight after work  there are people there in jeans and t-shirts, as well as suits. All in all, it feels very relaxed, but there's a kind of relaxed pride in the quality of service and food there. It's not too expensive for what it is  two glasses of wine, a beer, one starter (shared) and two mains (and service) came to £66. For the kind of quality you'd expect in somewhere twice the price, this is a real find.

g3XB0uONQ-iI-sbFEsTRnw.text: Lovely little european restaurant, nice food and good service!

T1_4wAPqSWlXRZ1ArwQo3w.text: If you call yourself "Laughing Gravy," you've got to deliver. And this place certainly did. Nice ambiance. Good bacon cheeseburger by London standards (I say this as London, in general, has shitty burgers). Truffle "Chips" (British for french fries) were very good, especially the addition of the truffle salt. Bread with hummus and pesto was good if a little skimpy. Good, professional service.

Cyrgvm0lKrk68id0gH7QSw.text: My partner and I were lucky enough to dine here on a recent trip to London.  The menu items were diverse and interesting--we chose the scotch egg to start, followed by the venison wellington and sea bass, and finished with the black cherry crumble--it was all delicious and skillfully prepared to develop complex flavors.  The restaurant also offered an intriguing cocktail menu, though I opted for what was a well-balanced martini.  The service was very warm and friendly, which coupled with a relaxed, comfortable atmosphere made for a very pleasant dining experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Laughing Gravy - London, United Kingdom. Venison Wellington, Sea Bass

PbzDErx0ri2xgSPRfwMkEw.text: Good food, good atmosphere, convenient location for dinner before a show at the Old Vic.

rqYPX50PsehCNSfpIadf8Q.text: Wow- that Mac and cheese was positively divine. Brie, goat cheese, and cheddar with perfectly toasted panko crumbs on top. Too good! Thanks, Laughing Gravy--perfect meal!

icpNqR72sxb96bVgTKnLdg.text: Very nice place, good service and, most importantly, excellent food. Arrived in the afternoon when they just stopped serving Sunday roast, so the 2 of us had to chose from the main menu. We shared a starter of fois gras and caramelised hazelnuts, which were looking pretty with their edible flower decorations and sweetly glazed.There were 2 fish dishes calling out and I decided for the roast monkfish. Nicely presented in a composition of fish, seafood, rice and vegetables, I fell in love with this dish. My mum went for the roast vegetables with Somerset Brie and was very content too. We also had desserts: light, sweet, fruit sorbets and warm peach crumble with vanilla ice-cream, all very good.Drinks and wine list also looked interesting and the staff could make recommendations according to our taste.All in all, we were very lucky to come across the Laughing Gravy... what a nice, unplanned discovery!

iEVw9qJ0beuxqrhq5JKwEA.text: Love this place!!  Have been here 3 or 4 times now, and have never been disappointed.  We had a 9pm reservation this time to celebrate our anniversary, and it was a great time, as the atmosphere was fantastic - just the right amount of buzz and life, while still feeling very intimate.For starter, I had the poached egg and asparagus with lemon sauce, light, delicate and great balance of flavours, I only wish my yolk was a touch more runny.  My partner had the venison croquettes, which although on the heavier side for a starter, the flavour was deep and mouth-wateringly fantastic!  My main was the scallop dish, perfectly prepared, the texture was silky with a perfect sear on the outside.  Beautifully presented on a herb mash, with a red wine jus accompaniment.  For pudding, I had the strawberry, chestnut and elderflower crumble - possibly the best crumble I've ever had!  Perfect balance of sweet and salty, and the scoop of pistachio ice cream was a great cooling flavour to go along with it.   As always, the service was attentive, professional, yet relaxed and unpretentious.  We will definitely be back again, thanks LG!

e3ZXn8IhkTGkmvpEeRxTKQ.text: We like this place. Staff are friendly and there's a relaxed feel on a Sunday morning but...our brunch was somewhat underwhelming. Eggs benedict were luke warm...the toast never arrived...coffee took a long time. We will return but I reckon we will stick to  the Sunday lunch.

mEt6z2y0w_UGMVwEAGlIfg.text: Comfortable cafe/restaurant in area of Old Vic Theatre.  Pleasantly surprised at the quality of the food and the lovely ambiance when we ate here for a pre-theatre dinner.The menu had a variety of foods and the staff was pleasant and helpful.Would definitely come back again.

onxw-NghlsCBWuKDT4kkPw.text: Very well-presented food and great choices on the menu, though the portion of scallops & champ for main was small enough that I was very glad I'd ordered a side (seasonal greens, delicious sautéed cabbage, but still nice and crisp). The skin on chips were quite salty, but I like them like that. I also love that they do wine in 500ml carafes - perfect size for one meal if you like red & your partner prefers white.

zyBaIDtsvVSVTrnKE-8ohg.text: I suppose the overall rating of any kind of establishment is based on the experience. The experience isn't just the food, the service or the company. It is all those things, and something intangible that makes you walk away saying, "what a cool place"This is Laughing Gravy for me. My waiter was brilliantly funny. He had a sixth sense in terms of what he thought I should order, and we had a wonderful evening. If you find yourself in London. Go! And challenge your waiter to a chocolate eating contest.

UeFvDLbZ_JIcR2z4V7iZJA.text: Food was good. Service was good. No wifi. Prices were very high for what you got. Had the lime donut dessert that was amazing!

kXd96Y1Uut6afVellP5aHw.text: Great place. We had our anniversary there, before to go to the Old Vick theatre and the stuff was wonderful and friendly. The food was amazing and the dessert to die for. I would Definitely recommend it

wSm0gzJ5WFPpfotDM4QWEg.text: Lovely setting. Comfortable, but a little loud. The food was fantastic and drink list well put together.

WMCvZQh13Ga-HTr9dKiO6A.text: Boring.Food and service were fine, but on the whole the restaurant is a bit 'meh'....nothing stands out, nothing special that makes me want to go back. A choice of only 2 starters, of which neither sounded tempting but decided to try them as, well there wasn't much choice for anything else, was trying to be optimistic but they weren't great.Even if i was in the area, I would try something new over going back here. It was just a bit too average, without any buzz or quirkiness to make it interesting or a memorable experience.Came here for Sunday Brunch but don't think I will be going back again.

YGEjiYuNa-_SA-s21n1f-w.text: My girlfriend and I were looking for a place to grab some dinner and happened to come across the Laughing Gravy through Google Maps as it was close to the hotel we were staying at (Tune Hotel). From the outside, it didn't look like much, but when you walked in, it was beautiful! Clean, friendly staff, great food, and that "at home" feel. We loved how the food was delivered on the wooden plates and the glass bottles for beverages. It was a great feel, reasonably priced and delicious food, highly recommend it!

U42zIbVbOySzfC6JEwmAjg.text: Easily the best place to eat in the area! Yes it's just a gastro pub, but it's a good one. Service was friendly and fairly fast, and the food was enjoyed by all 6 of us. Not that cheap, but not expensive. Well worth a visit. (it looks different to this photo, much more modern now)

4uqqI0j93fbHDH0QVRuzSA.text: An excellent little restaurant in Southwark. Very friendly and competent service.The food is fresh and well prepared. My wife and I had a pleasant evening! A small terrace gives you the opportunity to enjoy lush summer evenings. This restaurant is very worth a visit.

Q8BJVjyx84axrW3F20fo0w.text: Great restaurant tried to get in without a booking the night before but we were told no although the restaurant was only ten percent occupied

gybdgPbmipRF485fGj9c4A.text: This restaurant is recently under new ownership, and has been completely redone internally, and the food is really good. Definitely worthwhile making the effort to pop south of the river. The bread and bitter pudding was great.

4gNW20719E0-PPxINcGMQQ.text: We went to the Laughing Gravy for dinner. The food was delicious. Most of us had the lamb, which was tender and tasty. Unfortunately the service was slow and slightly incompetent - 1 person out of our group of 7 didn't get his main course until the other 6 had finished eating theirs. We had to ask where the pudding was because it took so long time. Also the waiter brought the wrong wine. But, all in all, the staff were all very nice and apologetic and tried their best. Just don't go there if you are in a hurry.

E7JKw4mpjZbUdi5lzSaDeQ.text: Came here for dinner.  We started with a scallop scotch egg and lamb dumplings.  The scotch egg was so delicious and juicy.   Unlike a traditional scotch egg, but a wonderful take on it.  The lamb dumplings were rich.  We shared the venison Wellington. This might be the best Wellington we've eaten.  So good and cooked perfectly!  I would recommend this place!

-K6cnYFo-yuHgaiG7JMLQw.text: We had a couple of missed food moments in London (two-hour wait for Dishoom, Bumpkin Notting Hill closing down, etc.), but we were very glad that the Laughing Gravy came through.A quick walk down Blackfriars Road, Laughing Gravy is a cute restaurant with a beautiful dining area and bar. The menu is offers dishes that infuse the essence of traditional British food with new-style cooking.I decided to start the meal with their spin on Scotch Eggs - with scallops and squid on a bed of arugula and seaweed. Very unique - and the flavors worked very well together! I don't think I'll be able to find another scotch egg like that one.For my main, I got the fowl with mustard sauce and white beans. Savory and just SO good. Every bite. Delicious. Great meal. Pricey, but it's to be expected. Quite, quite good.

photos.caption: Photo of Laughing Gravy - London, United Kingdom. Fowl with white beans and mustard sauce at Laughing Gravy.
Photo of Laughing Gravy - London, United Kingdom. Scotch eggs with scallops and squid at Laughing Gravy.

Ub4hFrgPrM8WIIBPhbuC-A.text: Pity about the restaurant's name, it way exceeds those expectations.  We ate there last week.  The wait staff were attentive and knowledgeable about wines, which were reasonably priced.  The food was artfully presented and delicious.  My cocktail was the best!  We will be recommending to our friends.

zwmVTfmr0hOQl1UWiR-S6Q.text: This is an absolutely delightful restaurant with great food and service.  We came here on a whim based on Yelp recommendations, and boy are we glad we did! This was one of our favorite restaurants that we ate at in London. We knew we had to get some kind of Wellington while in town. The deer wellington here was phenomenal. Wellington can be a difficult dish to cook since it's not easy to get the puff pastry just right, but Laughing Gravy nailed it! The creamy, mocha-chocolatey sauce underneath it was sinfully good. The pork belly was equally delicious. It was cooked in a cherry sauce and had a lot of excellent flavors and textures going on.  I wish I lived closer! Will definitely be returning the next time I'm in the area.

photos.caption: Photo of Laughing Gravy - London, United Kingdom. Deer wellington
Photo of Laughing Gravy - London, United Kingdom. Pork belly
Photo of Laughing Gravy - London, United Kingdom. Scallop and scotch egg

VEYKKpKStT4vs5wKjEWh6g.text: Friends and I (party of three) walked in around 8:30 on a Thursday night after seeing an appealing list of menu options and were told it would be 45 minutes to an hour - if not longer. We thought, fine, let's go across the street, have a few beers, explore the neighborhood options and if all else fails, go back because, hey the kitchen stays open until 00:00. So around 21:45 my mate goes in and asks for a table of three if it's not too late - clearly there was room to seat us. Unfortunately, the staffer said "yes, unfortunately it's too late to seat anyone." We were told it'd be an hour wait, so that's what we did - and still, we were refused service. Completely unacceptable. Not only to refuse the business from three hungry lads, but also the fact  we'd already shown ourselves once before and expressed interest in eating - leaves an awful impression. Won't be back.

WTN87-al_nlXeZxu9GMMiA.text: Came here from a suggestion by a local friend, on a Friday night I had already changed by into my American attire (Cargo pants and hoodie) and asked for a table for 1, thought they would turn me away because i didn't have a reservation (and my American dress), however no issue at all got a nice table.  Having looked at the reviews and menu ahead of time i already knew i wanted the Beat salad and Wellington so I ordered both.  I started with a half craf of some great wine suggested by the waiter.  The beet salad was the best ever, their combination of goat cheese, a beet sauce and the beets was fantastic.  The Wellington did not disappoint, properly cooked served over a mash and gravy.  Food was great, service was great a must try for locals and visitors.

eq0ri5Mq6TByUYpZQhI2yg.text: I was determined that I'd have some type of wellington in London while I was there.  So I resorted to Yelp and found this little cute place a few metro stations away from us.  Service was great.  Food was delicious.  I must say, though, I felt little stupid about my mild obsession about having wellington in London.  It was nothing special.  It tasted like eating a good piece of steak with a pot pie crust.  Gordon Ramsey's Hell's Kitchen must have made my expectation too high for this particular dish.  They did have amazing Mac N Cheese.  My bf who'd pick mac and cheese as one of this top comfort food said Laughing Gravy's one is one of his favorites.  I think that says a lot.The place is pricey (but I guess 3 pound sigh tells you that).  For two dishes plus a desert to share, one glass of wine, one cocktail came out to over 73 pounds (and at this time the exchange rate is about 1.56). And I didn't know that in England they add on "optional" 12.5% service charge to the bill.  I thought in European countries the price you see on the menu already reflects the service charge built into it.  Let's just say that I wasn't expecting that additional amount in the bill.  I guess I didn't do my homework right.

HpLAJ3pFlj3gN26wtZN9TQ.text: We were staying in London near Marble Arch, so the bus ride to The Laughing Gravy in Southwark was a bit of a venture, but my wife, son and I convinced my wife's parents and my aunt to make the trek to this quiet and somewhat off-the-beaten path location. Our meal turned out to be among the best we've ever had. The service was prompt but not pandering. Food was reasonably priced, excellently presented, and tested fantastic -- across the board, from the asparagus starter to the super food salad to the three-cheese roasted cauliflower macaroni. Ambiance was subdued, wth non-overbearing and pleasant music. Fortunately, we left room for dessert, which was extremely creatively presented and tasted even better. The restaurant also offers a library, from which you can select a book in exchange for a small donation. I highly recommend The Laughing Gravy if you are looking for an affordable, creative, well-prepared meal in a pleasant setting with outstanding service.

photos.caption: Photo of Laughing Gravy - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Laughing Gravy - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Laughing Gravy - London, United Kingdom

UPoiC1L9GCldjNqc5CSdnA.text: The Laughing Gravy is one of those gems. A small pub-style restaurant located just a stone's throw away from Southwark tube station offers a really delicious British food for affordable prices.Beetroot cooked in three different ways was a pleasant refreshing starter. Followed by an absolutely divine Sunday roast: tender meat marinated in Kernel Porter beer served with a lovely gravy (it wasn't laughing though, but made me smile). It was unquestionably one of the best roasts I had in London! Finishing off the meal with a mouth-watering dessert of chocolate filled of caramel and shortbread. All dishes were appetizingly plated up.The premises are small but cosy (with a few tables outdoors), plenty of light coming from a glass roof inside. A piano in the end of the room with an open sheet music book of an English sonata is a nice touch. Friendly service and more than reasonable prices.Will visit again? Definitely. estonianfoodie.com

photos.caption: Photo of Laughing Gravy - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Laughing Gravy - London, United Kingdom

MvcX8IxkSam3IheWBV-2kg.text: If I could give zero stars I would.  We walked in at 9:20 pm. We were starving.  There were plenty of open seats but we were told, "sorry we're closed". We asked what time they close and he said 10.  So I'm not sure how long before they close you have to show up but, whatever...  if 40 minutes isn't enough,  then I guess my money isn't good enough for them.

3TjhXwBdQ7q5FvZTC0LJ5w.text: Not very accommodating. Say closes at 10 showed up at 9:20 after walking 20 minutes to eat there and they said they were closing and wouldn't seat us. Maybe things are different here in England but in my travels restaurants seat you up until close to closing. I can comment on the food but I won't be returning.

VQhzLlTrSUWj9GARP8lbmw.text: The decor is nice. I had the lamb which was surprisingly tasty. The Sauce made the difference. Service was alright, polite and checked on us regularly. The portions are could be more generous but that is just my opinion. Would I come back? Maybe, there are many other places in London to explore. If you are on a date it is a good place.

photos.caption: Photo of Laughing Gravy - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Laughing Gravy - London, United Kingdom. Lamb

-BOFxScW2KoDVeo_MXy6Mw.text: Charming inside - the staff were so friendly and welcoming here! We did not have a reservation but they were able to accommodate us after a brief wait and a couple of drinks. The food was absolutely delicious - very fresh and really great presentation. I highly recommend having a dinner here if you are in London - make a reservation if you have your heart set on coming here. Thank you Laughing Gravy for a great dining experience!!

fWeL3Xoc5S3Sn14OLewRXQ.text: We stopped in late on a Friday evening with no reservation. The host was welcoming and friendly and let us know that a table would be coming up soon as the first batch of early diners were finishing up. We didn't wait too long before we were seated.The restaurant is cosy but with clean lines and with a conservatory roof inside that adds a light, airy feel. Within a few minutes we were seated. The British menu is full of appeal and interest. For starters I chose the scotch egg with smoked rabbit and seafood vinagrette which was just fantastic. Wonderfully presented too.For mains it was butter poached and braised guinea fowl with a chicken, cep and truffle hash and pureed carrots, samphire and ransoms. Wow, this dish sounded great from the menu description and more than lived up to the expectation. This is super competent cooking and a chef who really knows what he is doing. Every component of the dish was perfection and the sum was greater than the parts and guinea fowl has always been a favourite of mine. Here it was heaven.Would have loved to try the deserts also which looked tempting but will have to wait for next time. The staff were great. Food came in just the right time and was served deftly from friendly staff. It's gone straight to my list of best restaurants.Good value too for such high quality cooking.

QYrzWAbZ2CKAu2Di-nv_lQ.text: Stopped in yesterday for lunch and ended up returning for dessert!Lunch: Somerset brie glazed Portobello mushrooms and spinach with roast Heritage vegetables, braised leek and fennel, butternut squash and artichoke.  Delicious.  A smidge more salty than I like my veg, but everything was nicely roasted, and the cheese with the mushroom was a winning combination.I walked around for a few hours and couldn't stop thinking about how good the dessert menu looked, so I popped back in to get some.  Ended up being early for the dinner seating, but the hostess let me hang out and read for 25 minutes.  Speaking of reading - they have a library of books around the bar area.  fun!Dessert: Honey-roasted opal plum, peach, madeira and almond crumble with nougat ice cream .  REALLY lovely pudding.  The crumble topping was nice - sweet and crunchy, but not too sugary.  The ice cream was ok but not exceptional.  But I am from New England, land of creamery ice cream, so it takes a lot to impress me on that front.Overall, food was very tasty, but I felt like it was a GBP or two overpriced.

R-S1c1rcSTgOy_oiPAEhvA.text: OH... MY... GOD!  Sooooo good!  Best beef I can remember.  We went on a Sunday and I had a beef roast.  Then, the deserts.  The salted caramel thingy was a bit too sweet but we also shared a hazelnut chocolate one and a crumble. Both of those were well worth breaking a no-desert rule (if you normally have one).A fairly good wine list as well.  Highly recommended.

k-P1O65j0vHLcTTNjcZtSg.text: Went here for Sunday lunch with some friends. The area is the place's main drawback, as there isn't really much around, so its not a place you'll find yourself by chance.That didn't seem to hold the place back, though, as the place was full, so obviously, making reservations is useful/necessary. Menu is good, with everything from cocktails and mocktails, various starters, mains, dessert, brunch, and a good wine list covering Italy, France, Spain, Australia, US, Chile, and more.We had the Sunday roast, completely with Yorkshire Puddings, and it was absolutely delicious, and well-presented. Roast was tender, juicy and perfectly cooked. Gravy was on of the best I've had anywhere, and the Yorkshire pudding had just the right combination of chewy base and flaky top. Had their chocolate cake for pudding and it was equally delicious.

Fwa6fS2Ex0iBRGEUET5UTw.text: Totally loved it here!! It's the best place to eat, food is awesome!!! Prices are fab!! And the staff are lovely

WgSXXYdO1Niwbw4g4cQtYw.text: I chose this place b/c it was rated so highly on TripAdvisor, and I loved it because it's off the beaten path, certainly away from the uber-touristy parts of London.  I was looking for a neighborhood feel, locals-type experience and food made with love.So, the atmosphere and service lived up to what I wanted.  It was great to get out of the chaos of central London.  The food, however, was just ok.  Like Nish D. said, it was not memorable.  This is a nice place for a get-together with friends over some apps, wine and cheese; but if you want outstanding food that's reflective of local flare, this placed disappointed.  Nothing bad, just nothing great.

photos.caption: Photo of Laughing Gravy - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Laughing Gravy - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Laughing Gravy - London, United Kingdom

SyfNjUFFaIM1LX88WG_4cw.text: We had some friends visiting from America so we booked a table for dinner. I had the elderflower mojito which was very enjoyable. I ordered the heritage beetroot as a starter. The beetroot itself was lovely, however if you are going to put caviar on someone's plate please list it on the menu as not everyone wants to eat fish eggs. My review would be 4 or 5 stars if this didn't happen. Next I had the Mac and cheese which was very delicious. The portion size was huge and I ended up taking some home with me. My partner got the venison Wellington which he enjoyed although the pastry was a bit soggy. Everyone around the table enjoyed their food and it seems the sea bass was the favourite of the night. The onion crisps on top and the crab champ went down a treat. Overall the evening was enjoyable, the staff were friendly and the food was nice.
